summary: This document is an email chain between Assistant U.S. Attorneys in the Southern District of New York (SDNY) discussing how to handle Touhy requests (requests for government information in third-party litigation) related to Jeffrey Epstein. The emails focus on a request from a victim (Maria Lacerda) who is a plaintiff in a civil suit against Epstein's estate, and the complexities of obtaining or referring requests for materials from the earlier Southern District of Florida (SDFL) investigation.

persons.name: Steven Kochevar
persons.context: SDNY AUSA handling Touhy requests from Epstein victims; corresponds with colleagues about the process and refers to victim's counsel.

persons.name: John McEnany
persons.context: SDNY AUSA providing guidance on Touhy request procedures and expressing concerns about referring requests to other districts.

persons.name: Alex
persons.context: SDNY AUSA involved in discussions about coordinating with victim's counsel and criminal AUSAs on Touhy requests.

persons.name: David Jones
persons.context: Mentioned as having thought an approach to a Touhy request was reasonable.

persons.name: Sarah
persons.context: Referred to as a 'wiser Touhy head' in the civil division to consult on request procedures.

persons.name: Maria Lacerda
persons.context: Identified as 'Jane Doe,' a victim of Jeffrey Epstein and a plaintiff in a civil suit against his estate who submitted a Touhy request for documents.

persons.name: Robbie Kaplan
persons.context: Attorney at Kaplan Hecker & Fink representing the victim (Maria Lacerda) in the civil suit; the point of contact for the Touhy request.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier and central figure in the criminal investigation; subject of the Touhy requests and civil litigation.

persons.name: Alison
persons.context: SDNY AUSA who signed off on the response letter to the Touhy request.

persons.name: Maurene
persons.context: SDNY AUSA who signed off on the response letter to the Touhy request.

persons.name: Jeffrey O
persons.context: Mentioned in passing by John McEnany regarding the decision to use Steven Kochevar as the point of contact for Touhy requests.

persons.name: Rossmiller
persons.context: AUSA to whom the initial Touhy request was made, as referenced in draft language.

connections.description: Assistant U.S. Attorneys in SDNY collaborating on how to handle Touhy requests related to the Epstein case.
SDNY AUSAs coordinating on communication with victim's counsel and internal procedures for Touhy requests.
Kaplan is the attorney representing victim Maria Lacerda in her civil suit against Epstein's estate.
Kochevar is the SDNY point of contact for Kaplan's Touhy request on behalf of her client Maria Lacerda.
McEnany references a conversation with Jeffrey O about designating Steven Kochevar as the point of contact for Touhy requests.

events.title: Production of Documents to Epstein Victim
events.description: SDNY produced documents responsive to a Touhy request from an Epstein victim (Maria Lacerda) about a month prior to May 2020.

events.title: Follow-up on Touhy Request
events.description: Steven Kochevar emails colleagues about a follow-up call with requester's counsel to explain no further production will be made, and discusses referring them to N.D. Ga. or S.D. Fla. for materials from the Florida investigation.

events.title: Coordination on Touhy Request Procedures
events.description: Email discussion establishes Steven Kochevar as the point person for Epstein-related Touhy requests and plans to send initial guidance to victim's counsel.

keyFacts: The SDNY possesses FBI investigative files from the SDFL Epstein investigation but deliberately avoided obtaining any files from the SDFL U.S. Attorney's Office due to conflict issues, discovery issues, and the prior non-prosecution agreement.
The emails confirm that 'Jane Doe' in the Touhy request is victim Maria Lacerda, a plaintiff in a civil suit against Epstein's estate.
SDNY officials express hesitation about referring Touhy requests to other districts (NDGA or SDFL) due to regulatory complexities and potential lack of cooperation.

The correspondence reveals internal DOJ procedures and legal considerations (Touhy regulations, law enforcement privilege) governing the release of information from criminal investigations to third-party civil litigants.
